div.p:
XXXII 382
Berry After crossing the river
Lotembwa we travelled about
eight miles and came to
the straggling town of Katema
It is more a collection
of villages than a town -
We were led out about
half a mile from the houses
that we might make for
ourselves the best lodgings
we could of the ^ with trees and
grass, while Ntemese was
taken to Katema to undergo
the usual process of
pumping as to our past
conduct and professions
49 Katema soon afterwards sent
a handsome present of food

Next morning we had
a formal presentation and
found Katema seated on
a sort of throne with about
three hundred sittingmen ^ seated on the ground around
him and thirty women -
who were said to be his wives
close ^ behind him - The main
body of people kept at
a distance of fifty yards
and in a body inof a horseshoe shape
and Each party had its
own headman seated at a
little distance in front &
when beckoned by the chief
came near him as councillors
383
Ntemese gave our history and
Katema placed sixteen large
baskets of meal before us
half a dozen fowls and a
dozen eggs and expressed
regret that we had beslept
hungry - He did not like
any stranger to suffer
want in his town - and
added "Go home and cook
and eat and you will
then be in a fit state to
speak to me at an audience
I will give you tomorrow"
50 He was busily engaged in
hearing the statements
of a large body of ^ fine young
men who had fled from
Kangenke chief of Lobale
on account of his
selling their relatives to the
native Portuguese who
frequent his country - He
is a tall man about forty
years of age and ^ his head was
ornamented with a helmet
of beads & feathers, - He had
on a snuff brown coat
with a broad band of
tinsel down his arms He had a
large tail
made of
the caudal
extremities of
a number
of gnus - This
has charms
attached to it
and he continued
waving it in
front of himself
all the time we
were there He
seemed in good spirits
laughing heartily several times
This is a good sign for a man
who shakes his sides with
mirth is seldom difficult to deal with -
384
When we rose to take leave all
rose with us - as at Shinte's

Returning next morning
Katema addressed me thus
"I am the great Moene ^ (lord) Katema
the fellow of Matiamvo,
There is no one in this
country equal to Matiamvo
and me - I have always
lived here - and my fore-
fathers too - There is the
house in which my
father lived - You found
no human skulls near
51 the place where you are
encamped - I never killed
any of the traders - They all
came to me - I am the
great Moene Katema of whom
you have heard" He
looked as if he had fallen
asleep tipsy and dreamed this -
of his greatness, On explaining my objects
to him he promptly replied
pointed out three men
who would be myour guides
and explained that the N- W-North West
path was the most direct
and that by which all
traders came but the water
staat present standing on
them would reach the
loins - he would therefore
385
send us by a more Northerly
route which no trader had
yet traversed - This was suited
to our wishes for we
never found a path ^ good that safe
that had been trodden by
slave traders

We presented a few articles
which pleased him highly
a small shawl - a razor
Three small bunches of beads
some buttons and a powder
horn - - Apologizing for
its smallness I wished
to know what I could
bring him from LoandoLuanda
52 "not a large thing but
something small". He
laughed heartily at the
lim limitation - ˅ andHe replied
"Every thing of the white people
will be acceptable and he
he would recievereceive anything thank-
-fully - but the coat he had
then on was old and he
would like another - I introduced
the subject of the Bible but
one of the old counsellors broke
in and told all he had picked
up from the Mambari &
every one and glided away
into every other subject -
It is a misery to speak through
an interpreter - as I was now
forced to do - - With a body
386
of men like mine composed as
they were of six different
tribes & all speaking the language
of the Bechuanas there was
no difficulty in communicating
on common subjects with
any tribe we came to - but
doling out a story in which
they had no interest and
which I understood only
sufficiently willwell to percieveperceive
that a mere abridgement was
given, was uncommonly
slow work - - Neither his
attention could be arrested except
by compliments of which
53 they have always plenty
to bestow as well as recievereceive
We were strangers and knew
that as Makololo we had not
the best of characters, - and
yet his treatment of us was
wonderfully good and liberal

Wheeler I complimented him
on the possession on his of cattle and pleased him
by telling how he might milk
the cows - He has really a
a splendid herd of about thirty
He has a herd of about thirty
really splendid animals
all reared from two which
he bought from the
Balobale when young
They are generally of a white
colour and are quite wild
387
running off with graceful ease
like a herd of Elands on the
approach of a stranger - They
excited the unbounded admiration
of the Makololo and were a
clear profof of the country
being well adapted for
them - When Katema wishes
to slaughter one he is obliged
to shoot it as if it were a
buffalo - Matiamvo is said
to possess a herd of cattle
in a similar state - I never
could ascertain the reason
why they do not all possess
cattle in a country containing
54 such splendid pasturage

As Katema did not
offer an ox as would have
been done by a Makololo
ofr Caffre chief we slaughtered
one of our own and all
of us were delighted to get a
meal of meat after subsisting
so long on the light potage
& green maize ^ of Londa - On occasions
of slaughtering some parts
are in the fire before the
skin is removed from
the body - A frying pan of
these parts having been
got quickly ready my men
crowded around their
father and I handed pieces
388
all rounde - It was a strange
sight to the Balonda who
were looking on wondering
I offered pieces to them
but these were declined though
they are excessively fond
of a little animal food to
eat with their vegetable food
diet - They would not eat
with us but they would
take it and cook it in their
own way - and then use it
I thought at one time that
they had imported some thing
from the Mahometans
and the more especially
as an exclamation of
surprise is "Alleh" sounds 55
like the Illah of the Arabs
but we found a little farther
on another form of
salutation of Christian
origin "Ave-rīe" - (Ave Marie) The
salutations probably travel
farther than the faith My people
when satisfied
with a meal
like that which
they enjoy so
often at home
amused themselves
by an uproarious
dance - Katema
sent to ask
what I had given
them to produce so
much excitement
Ntemese replied
it was their custom
& they meant no
harm - The com-
panion of the ox
whewe slaughtered
refused food
for two days
and went lowing
about for him
continually - He
seemed inconsolable
for his loss &
tried again &
again to escape
away back to
the Makololo country
My men remarked
he thinks they will
kill me as well
as my friend &
Katema thought it
the result of art
and has fears of
my skill in medicine & of course witchcraft - He refused
to see the magic Lantern -
or pr

One of the affairs which
had been intrustedentrusted by Shinte
to Ntemese was the rescue
of a wife of that chief who
had eloped with a young
man belonging to Katema
As this was the only case
of returning a fugitive
389
to a chief against his own
will I have met with in
the Interior I am anxious
to mention it -- On Ntemese
claiming her as his master's
wife she protested loudly
against it saying "she
knew she was not
going back to be a wife
again she was going
back to be sold to the
Mambari" - My men formed
many friendships with
the people of Katema
and some of them poorer
classes said we wish
56 our children could go back
with you to the Makololo
country - here we are all
in danger of being sold
My men were of opinion
that it was only the want
of knowledge of the
Southern country which
prevented an exodus of
all the lower portions
of Londa population thither

It is remarkable how
little people fborn in a
flat forest country like this
know of distant tribes - An
old man who said he had been
born about the same time
as Mthe late Matiamvo and
had been his constant companion
390
through life visited us and
as I was sitting on some
grass in front of the little
gipseygypsy tent mending my
camp stool I invited
him to take a seat on the
grass beside me - This was
peremptorily refused - "he
had never sat on the ground
during the late chiefschief's
reign and he was not
going to bemeandemean himself now"
One of my men handed him
a log of wood ˅ taken from out of the
fire and helped him out
of the difficulty - When I
57 handed him some cooked
meat on a clean plate
he would not touch that
either but would take it
home - so I humoured him
by sending a servant to
bear a few ounces of
meat to the town behind him
He mentioned the Lŏlŏ ^ (Lulua) as
the branch of the Leeambye
which flows Southwards
or South South East - but they
had never gone far down
it as Matiamvo had always
been afraid of encountering
a people who from the
description given I could
recognizerecognise as the Makololo
391
He described five rivers as falling
into the Lŏlŏ viz-videlicet The Lishish, Liss
or Lise, Kalileme, Ishidish and
Molong - None of these are large
but when they are united
in the Lŏlŏ they form a magnificent
considerable stream - The country on its
through which the Lŏlŏ flows
is said to be flat fertile, and
well peopled withand ^ there are large patches
of forest - In this report hise
agreed perfectly with the
people of Matiamvo whom
we had met at Quendende's
village - But we never
could get him or any one
58 in this quarter to draw
a map on the ground as
people may ready be got
to do in the South

Keir
Katema promised us the
aid of some of his people as
carriers but his rule is
not very stringent for they
refused to turn out for
the work - They were Balobale
and he remarked on their disobedience
that though he received them
as fugitives they did not feel
grateful enough to obey - and
if they continued rebellious
he must drive them back
392
whence they came - but there
is little fear of that as all
the chiefs are excessively
anxious to collect men in
great numbers around them
These Balobale would not
go though Shakatwala ran
after some of them with
a drawn sword - This degree
of liberty to rebel was very striking
to us as it occurred in
a country where people may
be sold and often are so
disposed of when guilty
of any crime - and disobedience
we well knew that
open disobedience ^ like this among the Makololo
would be punished with death
59 without much ceremony

On Sunday 19th both
I and several of our party
were seized with fever
and I could do nothing but
toss about in my little
tent with the thermometer
above 90° though this was
the beginning of winter
and my men made as
much shade as possible
by planting branches of
trees all around and over
it - We here for the first
time in my experience in
Africa had a cold wind
393
from the North - All our winds
from that quarter are hot
and those from the South
are cold - but they seldom
blow from either direction

20th We were glad to get
away though not on
account of any scarcity
of food - for my men
by giving small presents
of meat as an earnest
of their sincerity formed
many friendships with
the people of Katema
We went about four or five
miles in a N- N- W-North North West direction
then two in a Westerly one
60 and came round the
small end of Lake Dilolo
It seemed as far as we
could at this time see
to be like a river a quarter
of a mile wide - It is
abundantly supplied with
fish and hippopotami
the broad part which
we did not at present see
is about three miles broad
and the lake is about
seven or eight long -
If it be thought strange
I did not go a few
miles to see the broad
394
part which according to
Katema had never been
visited by any of the traders
it must be remembered
that in consequence of
fever I had eaten nothing
for two whole days and
instead of sleep the whole
of the nights were employed
in incessant applications
to the water vessel and
was now so glad to get
on in the journey and see
some of my fellow
fever patients crawling
along that I could not
brook the delay which
61 astronomical observations
for accurately determining
the geographical position
of this most interesting
spot -

395
62 We observed among the people
of Katema a love of birds
of song - One pretty little
songster named cabazo
species of
canary is kept in very neatly
made cages having traps
on the top to entice their
still free companions
On asking why they kept
them in confinement
"because they sing sweetly" was
the answer - They feed
them on the Lotsa or lesser
bird seed of which great
quantities are cultivated
as food for man and
these canaries plageue
the women in the gardens
very much in the same
way as our sparrows do
at home do
396
I was pleased to hear the
long forgotten cry of alarm
of the canaries in the
woods and observed one
warbling forth its song
and keeping in motion
from side to side as
they do in the cage - saw also
tame pigeons
and the Barotse
who always
take care to
remind us of
Santuru remind
us that this
chief had
many doves
and kept
canaries
which had
reddish head
when the bird
attained maturity
Those we now
see have the
real canary
colour on the
breast with
a tinge of green
the back yellowish
green with darker
longitudial
bands which
meet in the
centre of a narrow
dark band
passes from the
bill over
the eye &
back to the
bill again
We

The birds of song here
set up quite a merry chorus
in the mornings and
abound most near the villages
Some sing as loudly as our
thrushes and the kinghunter
(Halcyon Senegalensis) makes
a clear whirring sound like
that of a whistle with a pea in
it - During the heat of the
day all remain silent and
take their siesta in the (63
shadiest parts of the trees
but in the cool of the evening
they again exert themselves
in the production of pleasant
melody - It is remarkable
that so many song birds
abound where there is such
a general ^ a paucity of animal life
aAs we went forward now
we were struck by the absence
comparative absence of
the large game and large
fowls - The rivers contain
very few fish - The common
397
fly is not troublesome as they
are wherever milk abounds
is abundant and it is seen
in company with others
of the same size & shape
but whose tiny feet
do not tickle the skin as
is the case with their
companion - Mosquitoes
are seldom so numerous
as to disturbrb the slumbers
of a weary man

Mead But though this region
is free from common
insect plagues and from
tsetse, it has others - Feeling
64 something running accrossacross
my forehead as I fell
asleep I put up the hand
to wipe it off and
was sharply stung both
on the hand and head - The
pain was very pungent - On
calling for a light we
found it had been inflicted
by a light coloured spider about
half an inch in length and
one of the men having
crushed it with his fingers
I had no opportunity of
examining whether the
pain had been produced
by poison from a sting
or its mandibles - No remedy
398
applied and the pain ceased
in about two hours - the
Bechuanas believe that there
is a ^ small black spider in the country
whose bite is fatal - I
have not met with an
instance in thewhich death
could be traced to this insect
Though a very large black
hairy spider an inch &
a quarter long
& three quarters
of an inch
broad is frequently
seen from having an
a process at the end of
its front claws similar
to that at the end of the
scorpion's tail and when
the bulbous portion
of it is pressed upon
the poison may be seen
65 pouring out from the
point

We have also spiders
in the South which seize
their prey by leaping upon
it from a distance of
several inches - When
alarmed they can spring
about a foot away
from the object of their
own fear - Of this
kind there are several
varieties -

A large reddish yellow
spider obtains his food in
another manner than either
patiently waiting in ambush
399
or by catching it with a bound
It runs about with great
velocity in and out, behind
and around every object
searching for what it
may devour and from
its size and rapid motions
excites the horror of
every stranger - I never
knew it to do any harm
except frightening the
nervous and I believe
few could look upon
it for the first time without
feeling himself in danger
It is named Selalée
and thmakes a is believed
66 to be the maker of
a hinged door for her
nest - The You see a
door exactly the size of
a shilling lying beside
a deep ^ a hole of nearly similar
diameter - The side of the
door lying upwards &
which attracts your
notice is of pure white
silky like paper - The
under side is acoated over
with earth exactly like
that in which the
whole is made - If you
try to lift it you find it
is fastened by a hinge on
one side and if it is
400
turned over upon the hole
it fits it exactly and the
earthy side being then upper-
most it is quite impossible
to detect the situation
of the nest - Unfortunately
this ^ cavity for
breeding nest is never seen
except when the owner is
out and has left the door
open behind her -

In some parts of
the country there are
great numbers of a large
beautifully yellow spotted
spider the webs of
which are about a yard
in diameter and the
67 thread on which they are
hung from one tree to
another are as thick as
coarse thread - The fibres
of the webs radiate from
a central point where
the insect waits for hisits
prey - They are placed
perpendicularly and
a common occurrence
in walking is to get the
face enveloped in the
web as a lady's face
in a veil -

Another kind of spider
lives in society and they
form so great a collection
401
webs placed at every angle
that the trunk of a tree
enveloped in them cannot
be seen - A piece of a
hedge is often so hidden
by this spider as that
the branches of which
it is formed is invisible

Another is seen on the
inside of the walls of huts
among the Makololo ^ in great abundance - It
is round in shape
of a brown spotted in colour
and the body & half an inch in diameter
The spread of the legs
is an inch & a half
It makes a smooth
spot for itself won the
68 wall ^ covered with of pure white
silky paper - there it
is seen standing the
whole day and I never
could ascertain how
it fed - It has no web
but a carpet and never
does any harm except
being an ugly neighbour
Indeed there is not
much reason in our
disgust at the curious
things -

21st Immediately beyond Dilolo
Berry there is a large plain of
20 about fifteen ^ twenty miles Here
Shakatwala insisted on our
remaining to get supplies
of food from Katema's
subjects before entering
the uninhabited watery
plains - When asked the
meaning of the name Dilolo
Shakatwala gave the following
account of the formation
69 of the Lake - A female
chief called Moene (lord)
Moneng-a came one evening
to the village of a Mosogo a
a man who lived on its
banks on the spot now
forming the lake on the
banks and asking for
passage but had a man who
livelived on the
banks but
who is had ^ gone
to hunt with his dogs -
She asked for a supply
& Mosogo's wife gave
her a good sa sufficient
quantity - Proceeding
to another village
standing on the spot now
occupied by the water
she preferred the same
demand and was not
only refused but when she uttered
a threat for
their niggardliness taunted
with the question "What
could she do though she
couwas thus treated"?
403
In order to shewshow what she
could do she began a song
in slow time and as
she uttered the last note
on her own name
Monenga-wōō - As she prolonged
the last note - the village -
people & fowls ^ & dogs sank into
the space now called
Dilolo - When Kasimakate
the head man
of this village her her the hunter came
towards his home and
found out the catastrophe
he cast himself into the
lake and is supposed
to be still in it The
70 name is derived from
"ilolo" despair because
this man gave up hope
when his family was
ruined - Monenga was
put to death - This may
be a faint tradition
of the deluge - and it is
remarkable as the only
one I have met with
in this country

Heavy rains prevented
us from crossing the
plain in front (N- N- W-North North West
in one day - and the
constantl wading through
the in water among
the grass hurts the feet
404
of the men - There is a
foot path all the way
accross but as these
foot tracks are worn
down beneath the
level of the rest of the
plain they are necess-
-arily the deepest portion
and the men avoid
them making a new
walk by their side -
A path however
narrow is a great
convenience as any
one who has travelled
71 on foot in Africa
will readily admit
The virtual want of it here
caused us to make slow
& painful ^ progress

Ants surely are wiser
than some men for
they learn by experience
They have established them-
selves even on these
plains where water
stands so long annually
as to allow the lotus
and other aqueous plants
to come to maturity
When all the ant horizon
is submerged a foot
deep they manage by
ascending to little houses
405
built of black tenaceoustenacious
loam on stalks of grass
and placed higher than
the line of inundation
This must have been the
result of experience for
if they had waited till
the water ^ actually invaded their
terrestrial habitations
they would not be able
to procure materials
for their airialaerial quarters
unless they dived down
to the bottom for every
72 mouthful of clay - Some
of these upper chambers
are about the size
of a bean and others
as large as a man's
thumb - They must have
been built in anticipation
and if so let us humbly
hope the sufferers by
the late French inundations
may be possessed
of much wit -
common sense as the
little black ants - of
Dilolo plains
